title: Will a team from England win the 2021-22 UEFA Champions League Final?
preds: 65% of the time Liverpool will 100% win!

Mbappé being a candidate for transfer to Real Madrid finally decided to remain at PSG where he is (not without raking in a few extra millions, of course). Spain's press speaks of "humiliation". Real Madrid's present squad will likely feel a kick of extra motivation to prove to their supporters and the nation that they deserve to be champions even without another expensive star in their squad.

The bookie's odds imply Liverpool have a 60% chance of winning. I think Real Madrid have been incredibly lucky. They have scraped through each of their last 3 champions league ties. However, because this has happened 3 times in a row, many will argue that it's not 'luck', It is actually a display of their experience and character.   I would disagree, in my opinion, and especially after looking at the stats, Liverpool have a slightly better chance than the odds imply.
Their key players seem to be injured. They are playing in France, which is not a very favourable area for Britons.

Predicted line-ups, team news and selection dilemmas ahead of the UEFA Champions League final between Liverpool and Real Madrid. https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/0275-151e9aea97a2-343677ff5a8f-1000--champions-league-final-possible-line-ups-selection-dilemmas-tea/

While I think Liverpool the more likely winner, Real are fully capable and beat pedigree English opposition in both the previous rounds. Liverpool have an awful lot going on just now with FA cup, league run in etc, and the stress and reduced time for rest, planning and practice risks catching up with them.
Looks like Madrid made it to the final so going back down to match current 538 chances. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
Liverpool strongest in defence and attack

Updating my probability now that we know the finalists. I'm backing Liverpool as slight favourites over Real, not just because I support them! Particularly in terms of defensive solidity I feel that Liverpool have the edge.

I thought Liverpool's starting XI earlier was quite telling; Salah, Thiago & Henderson all started on the bench (Edit: Robertson was not in the squad at all). It's clear where Klopp's priorities now lie.  Going back all-in, not because I don't think Real have a chance - they clearly do - but because I feel the need to commit fully, on one of the few topics that I closely follow!
odds given as -200 for Liverpool translates to 66%
We'll see if RM can keep it up...!
Still think Liverpool will do this.
I think Liverpool will be too strong as a team for Real.

Dropping to 70% now that Real beat Man City and Liverpool is the sole English team in the finals. It seems Liverpool has the advantage, but Real has been pulling off some desperate wins and could do so again in the final.

I have to come down *a little* after City's departure from the competition. Real have excelled thanks to their never-say-die attitude to the game, never knowing when they're beaten. They also have plenty of experience to draw upon. But Liverpool can match them in this regard, and I think the signings they've made this season have given them the squad depth required to compete on multiple fronts.
Liverpool by far the stronger side with a more tactically astute manager.  Has the side playing as a true team.  Real's luck to run out.
Historically favors Real vs. Liverpool.   so slightly leaning towards no.
Have to come down after the Man City loss yesterday.   Oh well. . . .
Reversing based on last nights results

Going down a bit. On paper, Liverpool seems like favourites to me but they will have a harder run up to the final because of the league and FA cup final. Of course, this could also help them stay sharp if they can deal with the physical fatigue. RM on the other hand has wrapped up the league, although they are relying on older core players who may still be fatigued (e.g., Modric, Casemiro, Kroos coming off before the 90th minute yesterday). Finally, RM in the CL is RM in the CL.
"Never write off Carlos Ancelotti or Real Madrid." Well, after 73' it looked desperately definite, https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1445543 but... Stamina & momentum is on Spain's side.
Man city out. Final involves one English team. English team the better team, but opponents have beaten two English teams in last two rounds and have goal scoring in plenty
The final is between Liverpool and Real Madrid. Liverpool are better on paper but Real is Real, as they have demonstrated again and again this tournament by coming from behind.
Liverpool slight favourites to win final
One English team in the final.  Can’t say anything more than 50/50 as it all depend on how they play on the night.
Following the crowd.  Not unlike a four year old playing soccer.
Getting closer by the match now...

Odds of Real winning are around 30%. Let’s call it 20% for them to win and break the tie: https://sportsbookwire.usatoday.com/2022/05/04/real-madrid-vs-manchester-city-odds-picks-and-predictions/. And if they win, let’s say they have 55% odds vs Liverpool. That means it’s a 0.2 * .55 = 12% chance of Real, and therefore and 89% chance of an English club.
Liverpool already through; City have a first-leg lead.
Real Madrid need to beat Man City by two goals tomorrow AND best Liverpool in the final for an English team not to win. Chance of first: 30%, of second 30%, of both 9%.
Villa 1-0 up on night. One more goal and the tie is even with the gone advantage and momentum with Villa. Dropped from 84% to 81% in response.
Dropping Real Madrid chances to 5% and all but counted Villarreal out
It might all be over on Wednesday.
Liverpool and Man City looking good currently. If both proceed this is a guarantee.
Both Manchester City and Liverpool have won their first leg semifinals at home. Liverpool are better placed at 2-0 but City take just a 4-3 lead to Villarreal.
After first leg performances, Liverpool all most certainly through and man city close.  Both sides looking stronger than Spanish opposition.  One of the two will win title.
Liverpool take a 2-goal lead into the 2nd leg; Man City also lead, and while Real may be slight favourites to win at home, they will need 2 clear goals to avoid ET and the lottery of penalties.
Liverpool to final 85%, Man City to final 70%. Therefore both to final 60%. Or one or other to final and wins it, (80%×30%×75%) + (15%×70%×60%) ie 18%+6% = 24%  So 84% overall.
Incrementing up as Man City squeaked by Real in leg 1

Have Real calculated that they will lose to City of they play conservatively, but have a better chance of they turn it into a high scoring lottery? So far it is 4-3 to City! But that still gives City a one goal advantage to take into the second leg, so adding two percentage points to my guess.
We should have a very good idea over the next couple of days but I would still say Liverpool and Man City strongest.
Over the last three years, two of the three champions have been teams from England therefore in the 2021-2022 season it will most likely be a team from England.
Liverpool and man city strongest teams left in the competition
Real Madrid and Man City might be close. Liverpool win over Villareal. Decent chance that it will be Man City vs Liverpool in final.

With an English team is both semi finals this means there is a reasonable chance of 2 English teams in the final making this question a certainty. One in the final seems likely.  I think there is more probability but it’s it’s still not that high.
I reate Pool-Villa 70/30 and City -Real 50/50, leaving a 85% chance for one or two English teams in the Final
Highly likely.  Liverpool and Manchester city both very strong.

Seems the two English teams are the favorites. Gerard Moreno from Villarreal has an injury. Real Madrid has a shot, but not a huge one.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-10726501/Villarreals-Gerard-Moreno-sustains-hamstring-injury-win-away-Getafe-Liverpool-tie.html
Liverpool are favourites in their SF; Man City have a solid chance of overcoming Real Madrid.
Liverpool and Manchester city are the strongest teams left in the tournament.
Three teams out of four.. Real has 50% to reach the final and then 50% to win it.. The remainder keeps the 75%..

Man C / Livpool / Villarreal / Real M.
With Athletico and Bayern out, I'm going to up this from 51.

Man City, Liverpool are the going favourite now over Real and Villareal. Seems like a higher likelihood of a England based team will win. There's in fact a good chance Man City and Liverpool both win their semi-finals matches which guarentees this outcome.
Very high probability now with man city or Liverpool

Man City and Real Madrid are even in recent matches but the recent wins have been to Man City giving them an edge.  Liverpool has the edge in matches over Villarreal so both English teams favored in their semi matches.  Bumping up my estimate to closer to the Crowds.
Following everyone else up since many are saying the gambling odds are improving for England and a key competitor is out.

It didn't occur to me to check till now, but there's actually a market for this: Nationality of Winner. England is currently offered at 1.36 decimal odds (4/11 fractional): https://www.oddschecker.com/football/champions-league/nationality-of-winner This gives an implied probability of 73.5%: https://www.aceodds.com/bet-calculator/odds-converter.html (Meanwhile, after a little further reflection, I'm notching my own estimate back up to 100%. Real Madrid were the better side in their tie for what, one half of football, across the two legs? I feel like they've ridden their luck enough just getting this far).

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
I'm fine just tracking public odds, I have no knowledge above that

If Villareal can do it, Athletico and Benfica can probably do it, too.
Apply some magic.
Current odds with equal adjustment put Man City at 38.2% and Liverpool at 40.4%. https://www.sportsbettingdime.com/soccer/uefa-champions-cup-odds/
Bayern couldn't win at home and are knocked out. One of Liverpool and Manchester City now looking very likely.

Bayern Munich was going to be the only real potential challenge to an English team, and they're out now. Real Madrid is the only potential real contender now, and they don't have much of a chance, imo.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
Bayern out and RM having to go through extra time combined with Ancelotti's reluctance to rotate...

With Villareal upsetting Bayern through an immense defensive effort it has cleared what should be a clear path for Liverpool to the final. (Liverpool with a 2 goal lead advantage over Benfica, and then a meeting with Villareal in the Semis as heavy favorites) I think Man City should come out of their side of the bracket, and as a backup a tied Chelsea/Real tie at this point leaves a real possibility of an all English semi final. Everything is pointing to a clash of the 2 English titans in the final; and what a final it will be. Update: Looks like Real has overcome Chelsea. So no all English semi on the one side. Still see Man City vs Liverpool as by far the most likely final at this point.

Real have surpassed my expectations a little, and I now feel that it's not impossible they could go on to win in the Final (but it would still be a big surprise). The headline news is of course Bayern crashing out which, to my mind, all but secures the trophy for one of City/Liverpool.

From a starting point of @alexandemeister 's helpful odds calculations, you get 58%. As a Liverpool fan, I have bump up the odds a bit! Bayern and Real are the only real challengers to the English sides and both are undoubtedly strong teams. Nonetheless, Real's embarrassing el clasico defeat indicates to me that they are not operating at the same level. Bayern's form in the Bundesliga combined with a shock first leg defeat also suggests that they aren't likely winners. Just speaking as a fan of the sport, both City and Liverpool are performing at an extremely high level, as was apparent when they played each other at the weekend. A factor that might reduce their chances is the intensity of the EPL's title race. There is also an element of randomness to UCL winners. Last season, Chelsea were far from the best club in Europe when they won. It is for this reason that I have not opted for a higher probability.
Reducing as it is unlikely Chelsea beats Real and Man City /Liverpool will face each other in the semis
Still have good chance of at least one UK team in each half of the semis.  The Man City/ Chelsea half is the most vulnerable after solid win by Liverpool.  Going downward a bit.
Slightly below 538 forecast to factor in a lower base rate.

Chelsea ran out 6-0 winners today away at Southampton. At the risk of stating the obvious, Southampton are not Real...but this will give the blues a much-needed confidence boost ahead of their second leg. It will still be a huge challenge for them to progress, but getting some shooting practice in can't have hurt. The real problem they face of course will be keeping Benzema quiet.  Not upping my forecast any off the back of this, because I already gave them a chance -albeit slim - of getting through. I would've reduced it though, had they not put down this marker today.  Also: should Chelsea pull off a great escape against Real, I think they'd be real contenders to go all the way. Their games versus Liverpool and City are always closely contested.

Current odds for Liverpool and Man City are +180 and +190. That’s a 35% probability. They are on opposite sides of the bracket so the odds that neither wins is a relatively simple calculations. 1 - (1-.35)(1-.35) -= .58 https://www.oddschecker.com/us/soccer/uefa-champions-league
After first legs of the quarter finals, Liverpool are looking good, Chelsea lost badly at home, Manchester City are taking just a one goal lead to Athletico.
I still think that either man city or Liverpool will win this.  Both very strong at moment.

Docking 15 points for poor start to QF, esp for Chelsea, even though Liverpool have slightly increased their chance of making this happen
Chelsea lost 3-1 at home, so need to win 3-0, 3-1, 4-2, 5-3 etc away (unless "away goals" rules have been reformed?). Possible but unlikely (3%).
Man City won at home but unconvincingly. Any win or draw would do, but any loss would be a problem. Probable but risky (60%).
Liverpool look more solid with a 3-1 away win. Fat lady hasn't sung, but on track (90%).

Liverpool are well placed to get to the semi-finals after their victory over Benfica. If Villarreal win the second leg, then their chances of progression increase. Bayern looks vulnerable should they get through. Chelsea will likely be eliminated by Real, while Atletico could shock Man City in the second leg. I feel Liverpool are best placed to win whoever they face in the final and with two teams in the semis, possibly, an English team looks well-placed to win the competition.

Taking it down a touch due to Chelsea's poor start in the QFs. They've left themselves a mountain to climb. On the flipside, Bayern have also made a poor start (but of course are more than capable of turning things around in the second leg).
Man City and LIverpool just won one of their quarterfinal matches

First legs of FCL and ManCity point towards an English champion and maybe even an all-English final.
However, whereas Liverpool has fully lived up to the high expectations as a top dog and will be hard to beat in the second leg, Athletico Madrid is still very close to advancing to the semi: one single injury or COVID-infection or the likes to a key player of ManCity's like deBruyne, and the next game could look much differently.
The way that Liverpool and Manchester city are playing right now, it is a high probability.
there are 3 teams from England still in it as far as i can tell.
Manchester City and Liverpool are very strong just now and I think one of those two based on current form will win.
Man City and Liverpool are heavy favorites, according to odds makers.
Well 3 out of 8 are from the U.K., but I rate Bayern strongest at the moment.
With  Manchester at 33%, Liverpool at 31%, and Chelsea at 7%, the probability of an English team winning are now over 70%.

Holding my numbers for now with 3 UK teams in different qrt final match and the strongest team (Chelsea) in the other half of the bracket from Man City and Liverpool, still gives good odds for a UK team.

Not with Canada just claiming one of the top three football spots
https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/60896263
Mirroring 538 predictions, which have MC: 29, Liv: 26, Che: 10. Don't see any convincing arguments in comments for why this would be wrong.

I've just the read the bit in 'Fast and Slow' where they ask people to individually guess the probability of each team in the league winning that league. The total of the probabilities for all the teams tends to add up to 250%. Anything other than 100% is a nonsense (in fact slightly less than 100% if you want to factor in COVID or war preventing the competition being completed). 
So what would you estimate if I asked you the probability of an Iberian team winning?
And then once you had forgotten that, asked you Bayern's odds.
Is this consideration priced in to the crowd's fairly stable current consensus, or is this a reason to drop things a bit?
Also, this forum is in English, and though it is international, that probably gives it a bias towards people for whom English teams are more familiar and present in their minds. There could be a risk of us confusing "how strong is the reputation of these teams" for the real question of "how strong are these teams"?
No one team has over a 50% chance, but combining the England teams its just short of a coin flip.
Most recent betting odds, 33.9% Man City, 32.4% Liverpool, 6.7% Chelsea

Before the tournament started, I quite fancied Bayern to go all the way. But on recent evidence (the 7-1 defeat of Salzburg notwithstanding) they've looked vulnerable, and their domestic form has been decidedly iffy. Meanwhile, Real will be a stern test for Chelsea, but I see the defending champions coming through it. And while City and Liverpool could be distracted by the premierleague title race they are embroiled in, they each have a kind enough passage to the Semis in this tournament.  fivethirtyeight.com give English clubs a combined 65% of winning the trophy, but I'm feeling bullish enough about their chances to go all in. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
Strongest teams are from England or Spain currently
Man City and Chelsea have to play their QF 2nd leg games away from home. Liverpool should overcome Benfica, but then face an away SF 2nd leg.
There are also Bayern and Madrid. The other teams would have only a minor chance.

There is always a chance that things could go awry with this but the teams from the UK left in the competition are very strong and I would suggest that one of Liverpool or Manchester City are most likely to prevail.
With one less English team in the quarter finals i.e. only 3/8 teams, the probability has reduced
Looks like there is only one English team that has a chance, will take the field.

Hedging towards the crowd, given I have zero inside insight.
It would be a surprise if Liverpool, Manchester City and Bayern Munich didn't reach the semi-finals, but Chelsea vs Real Madrid could go either way.
All three English teams have avoided playing each other in the quarterfinals.
3 English teams in the quarters. Likely that 2 will win (Liverpool and Man City) they are on opposite sides of the draw so both could be in final
3 English teams out of 8.  Two very tough draws against Real Madrid and Atletico for Chelsea and City.  Liverpool has an easier draw with Benfica, but at this stage, nothing is easy.

Great analysis by @steven_meyer. He comes out with a 75% chance of an English team winning the final, but because Brier penalties for being wrong are not linear, I'll move my forecast a touch lower. Now I'll wait for the semi-finals to end on May 4. It's even possible we'll have the answer by then, if only English teams end up in the finals.

3/17: English teams are 3 of the 8 remaining (37.5%). I'm going straight probability here with a slight bump (8%) due to a review of the odds that bettors are giving right now. Updated 3/17: Good feedback from @SE_meyer and my partner who knows much more than I do...poor statistics on my part.  Waited until the draw today to see if the English team ended up playing each other.

About as favorable of a draw in favor of England as I could have seen. (Probably only thing that could have been better would be Real and Villareal being switched) On the one side of the draw we have: Man City vs Atletico: Atleti can always be a bit of a wild card with Simone's physical style of play, but over 2 legs you would imagine the quality of Pep's City should win out pretty handedly going up against the winner of: Chelsea vs Real Madrid: This one is a bit of a toss up, Tuchel's Chelsea are a pragmatic and capable team (as can be seen by last year's championship) but not quite up the the standard of City, Bayern or Liverpool. Ancelotti's Real are still a very good team, but are going through a transition as their stars start to age. They aren't the galacticos 2.0 iteration of the team any more, but are still capable. I think City is pretty heavily favorite to come out of this side, with Real or Chelsea having a puncher chance. Because of this I expect a English team to come out of this side. On the other side of the bracket we have: Bayern vs Villareal: No offense to Emery's Villareal, but I think Bayern breezes through this tie. Maybe it is a bit tainted by my affinity for Bayern, but I don't see the 7th place team in La Liga even making it close if Nagelsmann has Bayern firing at even close to full cylinders. Taking on the winner of: Liverpool vs Benfica: Again, no offense meant to Verissimo's Benfica but I was very surprised they were able to beat Ajax. Klopp's Liverpool should certainly outclass them over 2 legs This side is much harder to decide who will ultimately come out on top. Bayern vs Liverpool will be a tie for the ages with both sides being very special sides. Between injuries between now and then, form on the day, and the tactical chess match between Klopp and Nagelsmann there is too much to call it anything else but a coin toss. From looking at the 2 sides of the bracket it looks almost certain England will come out City's side of the bracket, with the other side having a 50/50 chance (Liverpool or Bayern) with the one game final being a toss up between any of those 3 teams. This leaves me with a 75% chance of an English champion. (As much as my heart wants to say 0%, Bayern will take it)

Quarter-finals (First legs: 5/6 April, Second legs: 12/13 April)
Chelsea v Real Madrid (QF1?)
Man City v Athletico (QF2?)
Villareal v Bayern (QF3?)
Benfica v Liverpool (QF4?) Semi-finals (First legs: 26/27 April, Second legs: 3/4 May)
Winner QF2 v Winner QF1
WinnerQF4 v QF3 Final
Winner SF2 v Winner SF1
https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/draws/ There's a good chance a team from Madrid will meet Bayern Munich in the final.
Champions League draw at 11AM - if Bayern Munich draw Real or Athletico Madrid then the chance increases further.
Current 4 out of 16 qualifying teams from UK,  3 of the 4 leading their groups.  Liverpool has the best record so far of the UK teams,  Adjust with next draws.

An English team has won 47 of the last 67 UEFA Champions League Finals back to 1955 (20%). However, an English team has won or been the runner up in 3 of the last 4 tournaments, and the English team is ranked 2nd. FivethirtyEight lists English teams as three of the four top contenders.
The outside view is the frequency, 21%. This probability is adjusted taking into account the wisdom of the crowd (including betting websites and FiveThirtyEight predictions).

Thanks to other commenters I see there's a 538 page for that, so I'm just going to add those up (wish I'd looked for that when making my survey forecast). https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
Taking the outside view (my only option since I know nothing about European football) I count 6 wins from England since 1991. That's a base rate of about 20% so that's what I'll go with.
3/17:  English teams are 3 of the 8 remaining (37.5%).  I'm going straight probability here with a slight bump (8%) due to a review of the odds that bettors are giving right now.

As of 3/17/22 3 english teams remain in the competition (Chelsea, Liverpool and Man City). This means a 3/8 chance. So far, the showing of these teams has been very mixed.  The highest chance for a win lies with Liverpool given historic success, Chelsea or Man City have a relatively low likelihood at taking out the favorites, Madrid or Bayern given their historic match-ups. This leaves me with a low chance of success for an english team even though they represent the largest share of any country right now. Of course after the draw on 3/18/22 the chances might be a lot clearer.
3/8 remaining teams are from England, and they are playing better on average than some of the other remaining teams.

In the last 20 years 25% of the winners have been from England. So I'll leave that as a base case of 25% chance. I do believe that in sports there is a recency bias/skew given player contracts and "hot" teams. So in the last 5 years 5/10 finalist teams were from England with 2/5 years England teams won. So I'm bumping my odds up to ~50%. Current sportsbooks have two England teams at the top favorites and England teams make up 3/5 to win it all. Given that I'm bumping my odds up to 60% chance and extreme-izing it to 67% chance.
Small reduction in probability with 3 of 8 teams in last 8 being English, rather than the potential of 4
Blerk.  Football. English teams always have a chance, with a few teams. Not doing any research as no interested in football, so just going on feel and will,look at the crowd later.

2) Barcelona-27%

Figures according to five thirty eight
Of the 8 quarter-finalists, 6 are already known, of which two (Liverpool and Manchester City) are English, while Chelsea remain in contention for one of the remaining two slots.
Originally was going to forecast 32% based on what I think was a miscalculated implied probability from a betting site. I'm deferring to 538 with this adjusted forecast.
Slightly lower than FiveThirtyEight and betting markets only because the history of all the finals winners takes me lower.
Per 538, which can model this much better than I can.
Pure guess. Just barely aware that this is a soccer question.
Hard for me to improve on the forecast at 538. Thanks to @AnotherWorld  for pointing out their forecast.

Using 538 as a starting point: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/ We get a probability of 59%
Man. City - 26%
Liverpool - 22%
Chelsea - 11%

Three of the last eight will be English:
Chelsea, Man City, and Liverpool. If all teams had equal chances and fixture sequence didn't matter, would be 37.5% chance. But even in latter stages the champions league appears to have fairly well established pecking orders, meaning Lille, Benfica, and arguably (riskier) Juventus/Villarreal and maybe even Athletic Madrid probably aren't real contenders. Guessing 90%+ chance that winner will be one of Man City 20%, Liverpool 19%, Chelsea 9%, Real 12% or Bayern 30%.  So 48%.
I suppose the Congress out lower than crowd because I'm weighting "dark horse" likelihood higher.

Realistically at this point there are probably about 6 teams that I could reasonably see going all the way(In order of most likely to least likely): Group 1 (I will assume a 80% chance one of the "Favourites" win)
1. Man City ~27%
2. Bayern Munich ~27%
3. Liverpool ~27% Then a decent sized gap, then: Group 2(I will assume a 15% chance an "Underdog" wins)
4. Chelsea ~7.5%
5. Real Madrid ~7.5% Then a smaller but notable gap, then: Group 3 (I will assume a 5% chance a "Dark Horse" wins)
6. Ajax - 5% (As a bit of a sanity check, these numbers come out pretty close to the probabilities provided by FiveThirtyEight https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/ ) When we sum the probability of each the 3 English teams (Man City, Liverpool, and Chelsea) we are left with 61.5%. (Since I am only allowed whole percentage points, I am rounding down since my personal biased opinion is that I think Bayern will take it this year.)

Simply converting betting odds with flat adjustment to remove vig across all teams (and zeroing of teams with probabilities below the adjustment size). Showing 29.9% Man City, 21.4% Liverpool, 10.3% Chelsea, 3% Man United. No outside rate adjustment, if I did any it would just be moving chance out of Man City to Liverpool out of spite, but that wouldn't change the forecast.

Currently 1 team already in last 8, 1 almost guaranteed and 1 other in a strong position with a 4th looking better than 50:50. This would suggest high likelihood of 3 or 4 England teams in last 8, and these teams are stronger than the average remaining team in the competition by most ratings.  https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/fixtures-results/#/rd/2001309-2
